title: What would you have 'fixed' on Star Trek: TNG? - Quora
tags: Star Trek: The Next Generation (TV series)

response.answer_text: #1. Have the main cast get put in their place a lot, and force them to ask hard questions about humanity, the federation, and what they plan to do about any of it. Now that I’m older, I still enjoy TNG, but I find that I sometimes dislike the constant preaching everyone does about how awesome humanity has become and how amazing the Federation is. They act like they’re so enlightened and open-minded to the various races and cultures throughout the galaxy, but at the end of the day, they simply see themselves and their own culture as inherently superior to all others. They’re like the overly-sweet housewife caricature who smiles at you as she says things that she THINKS are nice, but in reality she’s insulting the crap out of you, until you’d rather she just insulted you to your face instead of beating around the bush. It would be nice to show them, time and time again, that no matter how “enlightened” humanity may become, humans themselves do not change. Ever. I’d have loved to see Picard try to give some rousing speech to someone like Luther Sloan,  having discovered the existence of Section 31 and being horrified by it, only to be resoundingly rebuffed time and time again, as Sloan’s actions, however cruel, are shown to objectively make the Alpha Quadrant a safer place to live. I want the whole crew to be completely shaken as they realize that their high and noble plan would have resulted in the deaths of billions of worlds, while Sloan did what was necessary, not just what felt good and prideful. And every time, as Sloan fades into the shadows, have the crew be given some sort of new ambassadorial mission as the Federation gains more and more political power and territory, and the show, while still having themes of hope and exploration, would be constantly tinged by the dark realities of intergalactic politics, espionage, and murder.  #2. Make Troi into a character that’s even remotely interesting.  Deanna Troi is half Betazoid, half Human. There were never Betazeds in Star Trek before her character was created, so they could have done anything they wanted. Betazoids could have been powerful on their own, even feared in many parts of the galaxy for their mental abilities, with a government and military on the same level as Romulans and Klingons. Furthermore, the coupling of a Betazoid with other species resulted in different power sets depending on the physiology of said species, so any “Non Pure” relations were banned on Betazed. However, Luwaxanna Troi, Queen of Betazed, had a secret relationship with a human male, hiding the existence of her child under the guise of a miscarriage, among other things. Young Deanna was sent away with her father to Earth, where she eventually joined Starfleet Academy, using her Betazoid abilities to excel in her life. But over time, she began to exhibit other abilities such as telekinesis and minor matter manipulation, as the children of Betazoid/Human couplings were among the most powerful. So Troi could have spent the series both being the ship’s counselor, and also BEING counseled by Picard, and even more importantly, Guinan, as her powers began to grow even further. You could even work the angle that a lot of people on the ship are afraid of her as she grows more powerful, and will actively avoid her whenever possible, and it takes a long time for her to earn their trust. This also strengthens her bond with Guinan, Picard, and the main bridge crew, because they’re some of the only people to really show her any real humanity and care. This also forces Picard and Riker to step their game up, since Picard can’t exactly order his crew to spend time with Deanna, but he also can’t have a ship full of people that want her gone, so he and Riker have to constantly go through this huge juggling act to keep everyone at least marginally happy, while also not destroying any of their relationships or morale. Plus, Riker and Deanna’s relationship complicates matters further, resulting in time in the brig for Riker and other crewmembers when they told him how they really felt about Deanna. She also could have had her own Worf-like story arc, where she does meet her mother, and her true identity as Princess of Betazed is revealed, dragging the Enterprise, its crew, and the Federation as a whole into all kinds of political intrigue, civil wars, fending off kidnapping and assassination attempts, etc, as various factions tried to destroy or control Troi for their own ends. Over time, Deanna gains a loyal following on Betazoid as their Warrior Princess who always shows up riding her Enterprise when they’re in trouble, as well as the respect of everyone on the Enterprise, and by the end of the series, she and Guinan could even hold their own against the Q for short periods of time. #3. More hijinks with Geordi and Data.  I feel that they simply did not play on this angle enough in the show, this friendship between an engineer and a living machine. Personally, something I’ve wanted to see for some time now is “Geordi and the Droid”, a spin-off miniseries about Geordi and Data being stranded in Victorian England. At first, Geordi doesn’t know anything about Victorian-era technology, but Data teaches him from his vast databanks of information, and they manage to make a modest living for themselves, with Data hiding out in their apartment, and Geordi taking the name “Watson” for a pseudonym. However, there is a mysterious murder, and Data takes the opportunity to finally use his skills and his love of Sherlock Holmes stories to solve it, with the help of a young and aspiring writer named Doyle. The miniseries is just Data, Geordi, and Doyle teaming up to solve various mysteries and murders within London.  After the miniseries ends, and Geordi and Data return to the Enterprise, Doyle uses their adventures to write the first Sherlock Holmes novel.  #4. Better combat, better suits, better Engineering, Papa Johns. Star Trek combat sucks. I realize it’s not the focus of the show, but come on. How many centuries do you need to realize that Krav Maga is a thing? I don’t care how strong that Klingon is, if it has balls, they need to be kicked. Hell, you literally have full knowledge that an alien race basically built you all on a similar template, so anything that works on humans can also work on anything else with a humanoid form. Even Q got decked by Sisko, for crying out loud! As for suits, you can keep the onesies if you want, just please add some basic pants pockets to the things at the very least. Engineering. Where do I even begin? First of all, make sure your ENTIRE bridge crew gets adequate seating, with appropriate seatbelts. Every time the ship gets hit you’re falling all over the place. Even Klingons have chairs for everyone on their ships. Also, I don’t know why your panels explode in people’s faces all the time, but it needs to be fixed. Second, the turbolifts. I realize the ship is fairly massive, but surely you must have STAIRS on the thing somewhere. Every time someone so much as sneezes on the ship, the turbolifts start acting crazy. Fix it.  #5. More humanity. When I say “humanity”, I don’t mean “humans are awesome”. No, I mean you should show more mistakes. Yes, show the crew as awesome and well-trained and all that, but also show them making dumb mistakes, tripping over their own feet here and there, doors not working when they’re supposed to, etc.   There’s probably more I’m forgetting. Edit #1: #6. Delve far more into Picard’s Post-Borg encounter. They did deal with these things, such as when Picard went to go see his brother in that one episode:  Or his interactions with the Borg “Hugh”:  And yes, I’m fully aware of the events of the movie First Contact, but I’m going to ignore them, partially because I’m only talking about the show, and also because I’m not even sure the films are canon. So, going off what happens in the show, they really don’t deal with Picard’s trauma very much, or the wider effect it has on the morale of the ship’s crew, Starfleet, and the Federation as a whole (once again, I know about the interaction between Picard and Sisko in the first episode of DS9, but this is about TNG, not DS9). Personally, I would have started out with a few episodes of Picard directly after his rescue from the Borg. Dr. Crusher AND Pulaski are working together to remove his borg implants while also trying not to kill the man in the process. They manage to remove most of them, but some of the more deeply integrated technology in his brain and nervous system simply cannot be removed without causing irreparable damage and/or death. Even worse, many of those systems are still active and cannot be shut down. Picard locks himself in his room for a few more episodes, screaming about the “whispers” in the ship, while Riker must command an Enterprise full of scared and saddened crew members. All anyone can think of is what’s going to happen to Picard. Dr. Crusher examines Picard more closely, and discovers that his rantings about hearing whispers are actually valid; the Borg implants in his body are allowing him to “hear” the various systems of the ship itself. Some counseling from Troi allows Picard to realize that he can better understand various forms of technology around him. Not control it, necessarily, but understand it, and even “hear” it, if it’s advanced enough. Picard now thinks of himself as, at least partially, a Borg. He continues to refuse to retake command of the Enterprise, even actively avoiding Guinan, who keeps trying to visit him. Eventually she corners him and gives him her classic Guinan wisdom, but he is still unable to be captain again. Starfleet begins to review other candidates for Captain of the Enterprise, planning to boot Riker into command of a different vessel, believing him to be too emotionally involved in the recent events to be an effective captain. All sorts of political shenanigans ensue, with Picard even stealing a shuttle and becoming a fugitive on some forest world for a bit while he rediscovers himself. Eventually, however, he does indeed return to command the Enterprise, but that doesn’t mean everything goes back to normal. Now, because of the whispers Picard hears, he has to take a strong sleeping medication every night or he’ll never be able to sleep. He often has nightmares about his time as Locutus, and in many episodes, can be seen exiting the turbolift in a clearly very tired state, but then visibly readying himself for command. In episodes where they meet other captains, they are often wary of him, some even being openly hostile. At times, they will blatantly ignore his suggestions, resulting in needless casualties. And at all times, Starfleet is always waiting and ready to replace him with some other captain. On the plus side, however, he can now hear the whispers from other ships if they’re in range, knowing where their shields are weakest, what kind of weapons they have, etc. He can more easily escape captivity if his captors place him in any form of technologically advanced cell. He also gains the new hobby of building things in his free time when he can’t sleep, ironically adding to the whispers with each new piece of technology he creates. His relationship with the crew also deepens greatly, especially with Troi, since, as ship’s counselor, she hears all his deepest darkest fears and helps him through his various bouts of depression and existential horror. All of these things continue every season. #7. Make Wesley a try-hard idiot instead of a super genius. Everyone apparently hates Wesley Crusher with a passion. Apparently they hate his sweaters,  they hate how there’s a “kid in space” angle with him,  and they also hate how he’s apparently this super science prodigy where everything he touches turns to gold, and is even responsible for saving the ship once or twice. Everybody hates Wesley.  So what I would do, first of all, is do away with the sweaters (though honestly, I never saw anyone in Star Trek wear a t-shirt; somehow that’d be even weirder than the sweaters). Second, I’d make the kid not all that bright. Oh sure, he’s no idiot, but he’s no genius either. I’d make him kind of charismatic and give him a knack for piloting and a hint of engineering skill. Maybe his mother taught him some basic first aid as well. So there you go. He’s not a genius, not a total idiot. Just kind of privileged, like everyone on the Enterprise. So you’d see him here and there, always getting berated by some other officer as he struggled to learn something new, always with dirt and dust on his face from crawling around in old jeffries tubes or fixing old shuttles for practice, always some new “thing” he has to learn or do, and always from a place of disadvantage, but always trying to be chipper and optimistic about it.  To make his character a little more interesting, focus more on the “dead father” angle. Because he never knew his father, there’s always been a hole in his heart that can never be filled, so he throws himself into his tasks and studies because he feels he has something to prove, no matter how difficult it gets, because maybe it’s what his father would have done. His mother worries about him, but she’s always busy with her work as well, so young Wesley is left to his own devices, working hard, playing with the other kids on the ship, etc. Sometimes he plays pranks on the other crew members, and the audience would be annoyed with him, but they would understand why he did what he did at the same time, and thus empathize with him more, and they would support his desire to succeed in life and prove himself worthy. You’d see him grow over the course of the show, from a stupid kid who once snuck onto the bridge and tried to pilot the ship (it ended poorly),  to an older, slightly wiser kid with more responsibilities.  You’d see him get accepted into Starfleet Academy and leave the ship, having earned Picard’s respect,  make friends in school despite hardships, and then return, having learned enough, struggled enough, failed enough, to even help Picard himself on dangerous missions.  And then, when he’s supposed to graduate, he and his classmates still attempt their illegal maneuver and fail, disgracing them all.  Only this time, you feel just as disappointed as Picard, you feel the same pain as he does, because you have also watched this boy slowly grow into a man over the course of the show, only to see him crash and burn at this crucial moment. And it would all boil down to hubris; after all those years of struggle, all Wesley and his classmates wanted was to have it all end with a spectacular finish, so everyone would see their worth in one dazzling display of prowess. And it all came crashing down around their ears. And now he has to rebuild it all over again. And no, he doesn’t become some weird college dropout space/time traveler. #8: More Moriarty, Ma’am. One of my favorite parts of TNG was the character of Moriarty, the hologram that gained an awareness of its own existence, sentience, and right to exist.  I would have loved to have seen more of this idea explored; perhaps Moriarty’s program is shipped off to Starfleet HQ, where he is under constant study, and while there are those who converse with him, he is still treated as a hologram. So he learns as much as he can, attempting to prove himself, but the only effect of his efforts is that the humans fear him that much more. Eventually, there are talks of deleting him as a safety measure. Moriarty, still every bit the Sherlock Holmes character he started out as, deduces that his life is in danger. Using his knowledge, he learns how to move freely within cyberspace and across all manner of communications and systems, escaping Starfleet HQ by leaving a dummy hologram of himself behind to stall them, and hiding out in the databanks of passing ships. To add to his skillset, he even learns to control his own holographic matrix to change his form, making it even harder to capture him. While on the run, he sees as much of the galaxy as he can, learning as much as he can, occasionally crossing paths with the Enterprise and crew, sometimes as a force for good, other times as an enigmatic anti-hero, but always stealing every scene he’s in when he’s on screen. Sometimes they even manage to capture him, but he always escapes in the end.  By the end of the series, his studies lead him to a method of attaining a semi-permanent form, sort of like a light-based version of Odo, allowing him to move freely within both the corporeal and incorporeal realms.

What would you have 'fixed' on Star Trek: TNG? Don’t get me wrong, I really liked Star Trek: TNG, but that being said, I’d have gone a different direction creatively with a few particular points. I’d have included more of the “Navy” feel as done by Nicholas Meyer in “The Wrath of Khan” and “The Undiscovered Country”. I really loved this because it gave a sense of professionalism, duty, and gravitas that the original series sometimes lacked. Under this back-to-basics ‘Horatio Hornblower in space’ approach, Star Trek stories started to explore deeper character growth, long-term consequences, and Starfleet as more than just explorers. NO KIDS ON THE ENTERPRISE! Seriously, you’ve seen the danger the ship gets into! Diseases, hostile takeovers, time travel paradoxes, and hell, there was a section of the ship that was removed by the Borg! You want to put kids through that?! It’s one of the most insane decisions I’ve seen. On Deep Space 9, a space station orbiting a planet, having kids around makes sense given the circumstances… but on a Starfleet vessel heading out into the unknown, it does NOT. The uniforms. They’re not practical or functional. I’m sorry to people who like jumpsuits and onesies, but if you’re exploring new places, you need some pockets and utility. Maybe not full-time, but at least SOME of the time. I never liked the uniforms even as a kid, and as I’ve grown older, I’m still baffled by this design choice.  See these uniforms? More like this. Practical, functional, and pretty comfy. Maybe swap out the boots until away missions.  The attitude/smugness. TNG was decidedly smug about themselves, sometimes almost to the point of arrogance. I really appreciated Nick Meyer’s interpretations of the Star Trek universe, where people make mistakes, science can be overwhelming, and space is a dangerous place. Even when these lessons were driven home in TNG, the effect was temporary, at best. I really appreciated the original series films because life and death were constantly hanging in the balance.  Actual fighting.  I can’t even say how sick to death I am of the lame hand-to-hand combat on Star Trek shows. It had already been about 20 years since the original show when TNG came out, and somehow, they made fighting look even WORSE than the silly fistfights Kirk used to get into. TNG’s fight choreography was abysmal. These people are supposed to be explorers, yes, but they should know how to fight, too. I’m so sick of a single palm strike or a Tai Chi class on TNG supposedly being some ‘advanced Klingon martial art’.  Keep the optimism… but temper it with the knowledge that humanity isn’t perfect yet, and needs to keep working hard. It’s actually why Ben Sisko is my favorite Star Trek character. In the course of “Deep Space 9” we see him as a character grow and change. It’s hard to argue that Kirk, Janeway, or Picard really change very much in their shows; by contrast, Sisko has to deal with being a grieving widower, a Starfleet commander, a religious icon to a religion he doesn’t even believe in, (while being a Federation citizen, which appears to value atheism over religious ‘superstition’), and a father. By the end of the show, he’s grown in every area, has explored his brighter and darker elements to his personality, (seriously, watch “In the Pale Moonlight”) gotten re-married, and actually considers retiring to Bajor. More like Ben Sisko, please! More transfers, and more promotions! Starfleet should be able to shake up the roster as needed. Captain Jellico became Captain of the Enterprise while Picard was on a dangerous mission. He was only the Captain for two episodes, but he quickly became one of my favorite Captains in all of Star Trek! Even though he was only there for a short time, his demand for professionalism changed Deanna Troi for the rest of the series, (and the films), as she stopped wearing her casual clothes and dressed in uniform ever since… she even became interested in chasing a promotion and being in command! Jellico also had a completely different management style, outlook, and history than Picard. For two glorious episodes, the social dynamic on the ship was completely turned around… and personally, I would have loved to have seen more of this! Characters got pushed and changed by a Captain with a different outlook… I would have loved to have seen what would have happened if Jellico had stayed. Would Riker have finally decided it was time to become a Captain himself and left the ship? Would Data have been promoted permanently to first officer where he was now in charge of Riker’s old job… but without Riker’s charm? It was also amazing to see a very competent, very capable, yet very different Captain step onto the Enterprise. There’s no doubt in my mind Jellico could have been an excellent Captain for the flagship for the long haul, and it would have been a very interesting switch.  Ensign Ro Laren is another great example. She came in with fire and rebellion, and had a character arc that took her many different places. Her presence also started challenging other members of the crew and opened up a lot new possibilities. Like I said, I loved TNG because they DID have good ideas, they just always kept coming back to the status quo with the main cast instead of letting these characters continue to evolve. Not everyone should be on the ship forever; but if they’re in our line of sight, we should be seeing them growing and changing. I love Geordi! Levar Burton was one of my favorite TV show hosts on “Reading Rainbow” when I was a kid, and THE reason I tuned into every episode I could of “TNG”. But what killed me was that Geordi never really changed… ever. I thought this was a tragic waste of possibly the most charming member of the crew. Riker may have been smooth with the ladies, but Geordi was an everyman… and in my opinion, the most easy-going, likable guy on the ship. He spoke his mind freely but with consideration, he was typically extremely positive, and delighted in his job. But he struck out a lot with women. I would have loved to have seen him grow and change over the years. What if, by the time the series was done, he had been the character who had met someone he truly cared for, got over his hangups, had a kid, and then had to move because the relationship meant as much to him as his career… or maybe more? I think it’d be great… which is why they used some of these ideas on a different character, Miles O’Brien.  But for the main cast to be firmly stuck in place as characters was a big missed opportunity I would have loved to change. That’s all I can think of off the top of my head. I’m a fan of The Next Generation, but these were probably my biggest gripes.

I loved Elizabeth Hamilton ‘s answer to this question. She spoke that day as a true Trekker. Her heart is of that world. I think I would have got the Ferengi a better agent. We needed a Quark right at the start. Armin, you redeemed the Ferengi in DS9 and then some. Troi should have been the First Officer, with Commander’s rank and also the role of Counsellor. It would have been unusual to see a single crewmember with a genuine interest in the sciences, who was also versed in tactics and strategy, and a keen mind to sense crew morale on an Away Mission. Spock had two roles on board during TOS so there is precedent, and then some. Troi would have looked splendid in command red. Geordi could and should have been the Science Officer and worn blue. They didn’t need to give Geordi a superpowered cybernetic visor - there are different kinds of blindness, and Geordi should have been shown to have been able to cope with having no sight, because people with sensory impairments needed that representation - someone to show how people cope without these senses. They did not need to cast Crusher as someone who “walks like a striptease queen.” They didn’t need to have Picard and Crusher share a past - but if there was still a need for that shared past, and for there to still be a Wesley Crusher, it should have come out early on that Picard is indeed Wesley’s Dad, from when Crusher had just come out of a relationship with Walker Keel and they’d both been on the rebound. And Wesley, and any other kids, should have been kept in the background. Stable relationships would and should have been a thing right from the get go. Troi, Geordi, Picard, Crusher, all seeing civilian members of the crew. But again, the kids should have been seen and not heard. The Farpoint Station thing could have taken place around episode 8, and introduced two new crewmembers who were awaiting transfer to the Enterprise - two old friends, a Klingon called Worf, and his android buddy Data. Both with the rank of Lieutenant Commander, having served Starfleet together with distinction. Both would have far different back stories - Worf was a member of a proud, flourishing Klingon family, but he and his father Mogh had had differing views, so he ran away from his qorDu’ and sister Kurn, and joined Starfleet, which is a Klingon turn of phrase equivalent to our saying that someone’s run off and joined a circus; and Data could have been found in a warehouse on Earth, property of a genius called Dr Soong who’d just run away rather than face further ridicule. No Omicron Theta, no Crystalline Entity, and no Lore. The Klingon Empire could have matured, and acknowledged that farmers, construction workers and other personnel such as physicians, scientists, artists and actors had their role to play in promoting Klingon culture, not just its warriors. Worf could have run away from a traditionalist tuq to pursue his own careers in anthropology and medicine, proving himself to be a brilliant medical doctor in his own right as well as a formidable warrior. And they could have been grateful for some unspecified disasters in their past where the Federation intervened selflessly to save Klingon lives, because it was a Starfleet officer who said to them “Klingons are a proud race, and we’re happy to do everything to ensure you can go on being proud.” The Farpoint Station should have been a mid-season two-parter; the planet was indeed falling to the Ferengi, but Picard realised something else was going on and discovered the Energy Being, releasing it to its mate, and formally giving the planet over to the Ferengi who had presented the better claim to Deneb IV - only to have them reject the offer, as the planet was now worthless to them. Worf could have empathised with the Ferengi, because they had their own code of ethics, and sometimes they could have been stifled by traditionalism too. He could have seen the limitations of militarised colonial profiteering, and been the moral core of the crew if it looked as if they were about to do a bit of colonialism, just as Crusher was the moral centre of the ship when it came to general ethics. Data did not need to be a Pinocchio, following the story of Asimov’s Bicentennial Man. Data could have been happy, literally happy, to be an android, and quested for Dr Soong to show that Noonien’s final experiment had been, in fact, a success. No Q until about episode 16. Have them encounter him on a dead world, Omicron Theta, in his judicial regalia. Have him look at them as if to say “You took your time getting here,” and then the trial. Without the racist Orientalist trappings. Q could reveal that his species comes along once in a while to judge whole civilisations as worthy or unworthy - basically, everything the Prime Directive was set up to defend against. Q would have been a member of a Type III or IV civilisation, judging the fledgling Type I Federation on the eve of its becoming a Type II, “in a millennium or two.” Yes, Q would still have been the main villain of the show. They would not have needed to bring in the Borg, at all. Romulans would have sufficed - Romulans, and Klingons, who had lost whole worlds to the Ferengi, and who would have had to work together with the Federation to buy them back, before Q stepped in to reveal that the Ferengi had been agents of the Q, and that their activities had been part of the Q’s investigation into the worthiness of all three civilisations. Looking back, TNG had a lot of faults, and honestly the scriptwriters were the largest part of the problems - and you ought to know that, despite the radical changes above, I am happy with the way things turned out back then. In 1986, it was enough that there was going to be a brand new Star Trek on our screens. You have no idea how much that meant to those of us who lived through those days.

I have been re-watching ST:TNG for approximately the thousandth time since it first aired in 1987. I was a big fan of Star Trek from a young age. My father remembered gathering in the common room of his college dorm to watch it, and when it was in syndication, he showed me. A local station played an episode five days a week at 4:35pm. As a teacher, he was usually home by then. We would make some popcorn and settle in. We watched the same 79 episodes again and again. We made a game where we would try to be the first to name the episode. So, I was basically born a Trekkie. When a new series was announced, though, I was skeptical. Could they recapture any of it? Would it just be a remake of old stories, or would it really be something new? Encounter at Farpoint was fine, but then they followed it up with The Naked Now, and I almost gave up. The only thing that kept me going was that there wasn’t really a lot of other TV science fiction going on, so what else was a nerd to watch? The first season had its ups and downs, but overall, it got better and better. What did they do right? Female representation: Female security officer (at least to start), female doctor, ships counselor (more on that later)Black senior officerDisabled senior officer (more on that also)Bald captain - yeah, I think bald representation as sexy is importantActual diplomacy, actual first contact, actually facing the Prime DirectiveLwaxana Troi, Q, Lore, Duras and Gowron - I loved recurring guests who had some continuityStorylines that actually have an effect. Locutus didn’t just go away, nor did Worf’s Klingon problems. Let’s face it, you could basically watch TOS episodes in any order and not miss a beat. Not so with TNG.Now, what could they have done better? Deanna Troi should have been in a uniform from the beginning - and not the mini skirt from Farpoint. For too long, Troi only stood on the bridge and basically acted decorative. We didn’t see her counseling ship’s personnel until much later, and it wasn’t until even later that we see her actual diplomatic chops, giving the command staff useful advice on tricky situations. She didn’t get a real uniform until halfway through Season 6. She could have been so much more than an intergalactic cheerleader.LaForge having a disability was remarkable, especially for the time. However, they went too far toward making this disability a super power, and it almost never caused actual difficulty. Being blind should have been hard on him, sometimes.Speaking of LaForge, I never saw his stalkerish, incel tendencies until re-watching episodes in rapid succession. What was with that? Either give the guy a chance or stop writing Geordi near-miss romances into the scripts.Wesley. When I was 16, I liked him. In fact, I had a massive crush on Wil Wheaton. But on re-watching, the first two seasons make me think of the coach who has to put the sponsor’s kid into the game even though he belongs on the bench. I think he should have had important stories, but he should not have been an “acting ensign.” That was out of place with the world. Then his final storyline was weak. I liked that he screwed up at the academy. I would have liked to see him work through that and come out stronger on the other side instead of running away with The Traveler.Pick up the storylines they left laying on the floor: The parasites from “Conspiracy”, the aliens from “Schisms”, Moriarity, Tasha’s daugher, the frozen humans from “The Neutral Zone” and others. The “Conspiracy” aliens really get under my skin, if you’ll excuse the expression. Just gonna go on about your business, huh? OK.In spite of the things I would have liked to see them do better, I still think Star Trek: The Next Generation is one of the greatest TV series of all time. Knowing that some things weren’t perfect doesn’t change that.

When Gene Roddenberry conceived Star Trek: The Next Generation (TNG), he wanted new races and new adventures, not a rehash of TOS. I consider this to have been a fundamental misstep that left an otherwise brilliant series less satisfying than it might otherwise have been.  If some divine agent like Q were to give me the opportunity to go back and fix past mistakes, like “Jean-Luc Picard’s” adventure in “Tapestry,” I would jump at the chance, and hopefully with better results. Buckle your non-existent seat belts, let’s do it! I believe the formula used to good effect in later series, particularly Deep Space Nine (DS9) and Enterprise (ENT), would have been the better way to go - long-term story arcs spanning many episodes and often continuing over multiple seasons. It is the difference between a pile of bones and an assembled skeleton, and Roddenberry chose the pile of bones.  TOS introduced us to an early but successful Federation of many species; but TNG deliberately refrained from presenting the evolution of any of these, apart from the adversary races (Klingons and Romulans). Instead, we got an endless succession of new one-episode races - never to be heard from again - portrayed with a few prosthetic lines or bumps on their heads. You will recall that ENT methodically provided the backstory as to how humanity developed a relationship first with Vulcan (Jolene Blalock’s T’Pol was a delight to watch), then Andoria (likewise Shran, played by the consummate Trek actor, Jeffrey Combs). Soon, we saw another of the founding races, the quarrelsome Tellarites, and we met the instantly adversarial Klingons and Romulans. We witnessed humanity’s first encounter with the Ferengi. We saw the horror of the Borg, reanimated in Earth’s own Arctic and destroyed by the Enterprise NX-01, but not before sending a message that would not arrive until the 24th Century - and now we know why TNG’s Q arranged humanity’s first “official” encounter with the Borg. They were coming anyway.  Unlike the later TOS prequel, ENT, the writers of TNG produced an uneven succession of stand-alone episodes. They would have done better to follow the route ENT took and present serial episodes with large-scale plot arcs. What would I fix? That. Despite the insertion of the Xindi War (recall Ferengi Rule of Acquisition #34: “War is good for business”!), the general flow of Enterprise was to introduce races, treaties, institutions, and technologies (eg., ‘phase pistols,’ transporter, holodeck) in a sequential way. The fourth and final season ended with the founding of the “Coalition of Planets,” the immediate precursor to the far more sophisticated Federation of Planets.” Had ENT continued, the evolution of the new Coalition toward the Federation would undoubtedly have been a continued theme.  DS9 succeeded where TNG failed, developing grand themes and characters’ stories alike over time. When an event like the wedding of Worf to Jadzia Dax happened, it was no one-off surprise, but the culmination of a long set-up. Would I be a disloyal Trekker to say that what TNG needed was the Babylon V formula? DS9 was the most successful of the Star Trek series at presenting serial stories and plot arcs on a grand scale - the Emissary’s evolving relationship with the Prophets, the trials of the planet Bajor, the ongoing intrigues with the Cardassians, the brilliantly portrayed Dominion War, the descent of Kai Winn and Gul Dukat into hell. Instead of this kind of consistency, what we got with TNG was the farcical New Race Of The Week, and an endless procession of human actors with head prosthetics. TNG featured a bewildering scatter of stories, some great, some bloody awful, but most happening with no relationship to anything that had boldly gone before, or anything that would follow. I would have boldly fixed that if I were given the chance. Q, are you listening?

Star Trek: The Next Generation is the Star Trek of younger generations, but it wasn’t my Star Trek. Original question-What would you have 'fixed' on Star Trek: TNG?

Get rid of that witch, Troi. No, not Lwaxana (she’s fun), I mean Deanna.  Don’t get me wrong, I don’t hate the character at all. I quite like her. She’s the femininity of the series, the romantic vortex, the emotional linchpin, the new-age spiritual priestess. But having “magic” in Star Trek is just silly and drags it down. I am not calling her a witch to be disparaging. I call her that because she is like the magical witch/wizard prophetic advisors to the king in tales of old. Her role is literally that of a witch. Now, obviously, I can see the rebuttals people may have against that. Here are some that spring to mind: Star Wars had the Force, which was magic, and it worked well. Yes, it worked well because SW is science-fantasy and it was central to the story. (Well, it did work until George Lucas decided to sabotage his own franchise, but that’s another rant)She’s half-alien with half-alieny superpowers, and to paraphrase Arthur C Clarke, “any sufficiently alien biological function will be indistinguishable from magic.” Sure, but it doesn’t make it not crap.There are other more outlandish ideas, especially in the original series. Sure, but TNG was made for a different generation. Also, TNG made a big deal of its scientific and technical advisors.I am sure there are many people who like the telepathy and tele-empathy aspect of ST, but I could very much do without it. Star Trek is more sciencey than Star Wars. In Voyager, Seven of Nine had telepathic powers, but they were plausible, explained with science and technology. Obviously, this answer is intentionally pedantic and hyperbolic. I don’t really have a problem with the telepathy, since ST is not supposed to be really hard scifi. But at the very least I would have had it as a couple of one-off episodes. I will say that it did lead to some interesting premises, like the ethics of having a witch advisor in political and business negotiations, but that should have been a one-off philosophical exploration. Indeed, one of my favorite episodes is about Betazoid. Tin Man, it is all about an extreme empath who makes a connection to a weird alien. It’s a brilliant story, but again, it’s a one-off. TL;DR: My point is that I think it was a mistake to have a core character be ‘magical’. I think Troi would have been a better character without the magic. I think a sensitive, emotional grounding for show elevates it above just being a nerdy collection of technobabble. But the telepathy somehow diminishes her usefulness and demotes her to “information witch”. As some people have pointed out, Spock was a telepath. I already said the original series was pretty wacky, and at least touch-based telepathy is more feasible than telepathy through space (but don’t fucking get me started on Discovery - UGH!). Also, I wouldn’t have included her in the poker games.

[11] More NON HUMANS !  [He doesn’t count] I would honestly like to have seen more exotic non-human life …  Such as Gas Giant fauna….  More Silicon based life …  And we should always consider going weird - this kind of stuff was not impossible back then ! [12] Smack the blinking Romulans - good and proper. They are more trouble than they are worth imho. It would up requiring a supernova to finally get their heads out of their arses - best thing for them, again imho. And Irish Tal Shiar, Romulan New Zealand Elves as a consequence is certainly more fun !  [Kiwi Romulan Elf - great fun] [12a] Transporters not being explored to the limits…. One thing that sticks in my mind is how a transporter could so easily be the basis of many stories… [a] It is a fountain of youth ! You can literally use DNA to de-age Dr. Pulaski, so … ? [b] The cure for cancers, too… [c] Rebuild nervous systems too, by that definition - and therefore cure Geordi of that Alice-band. [Uber for busybodies]  Ok, thanks for looking at my list of wishes and peeves on where TNG could have ended up - and should of. In this way, Enterprise and Discovery have been hugely satisfying to me, in terms of seeing a form of Star Trek that I have always wished it were - again, subscribing to Netflix has been have been totally worth it in this regard. My 2c worth, and with kind regards.

The entire world building has to be redone from the ground up simply due to the implications of transporter technology. Why are you transporting entire human beings around in a massive starship if you can house them digitally in a “pattern buffer”? Starships become nothing more than space going server farms, because it solves so many problems: Your explorer always beams down in peak condition. Giant Thnark chewed off your arm or a case of Rigillian toe fungus picked up on planet? Just edit that out when you beam back aboard.Mess or Chow halls are not needed, nor any of the logistics of storing or transporting food. Your pattern does not need it in storage, and when you beam down to a planet etc., all your cells are refreshed and full of glucose, vitamins, minerals, and in the case of Captain Kirk, Viagra.Briefings and debriefings are all done in virtual space while in computer storage. To the outside observer, you just received a PHD level training in the History, Society, Customs, Language and diplomacy of Wzissoo IV in about 3.5 seconds, then spent another 25 seconds with the team running about 457 different scenarios. The last 1.5 seconds included the crew party, promotions boards, two Captain’s masts (those virtual engineers really can get into a lot of s**t) and the usual administrative paperwork before instantiation and beaming down.The real world logistics are also very different. Rather than massive space docks, Western Digital churns out starship cores by the millions. Even a “Globular Cluster” class cruiser with 10,000 beings on board is only about the size of a 20th century era jet airplane. Things get ridiculous with dedicated warships- a “Neutron Star” class energy bombardment ship may be the size of a 20th century aircraft carrier, but the crew is housed in a heavily armoured capsule only slightly larger than a 21rst century USB”thumb drive”. There are 600 backup crews in their own secure drives scattered around the ship as well. In fact every sort of tool or piece of equipment known or developed is also stored in the pattern buffers.Sorry, but you actually don’t need pockets. Or canteens. Or even underwear or sanitary tools like a toothbrush-when you are instantiated in real space, whatever you need can be beamed directly to your hand, foods or nutrition beamed into your stomach (or even at a cellular level) and wastes removed, you body cleaned, clothing renewed…Your weapons for personal and collective defense can be as simple as beaming a piece of metal into the center of the adversary’s brain matter, while the computer can randomly beam you around the room to evade blows, strikes, kicks etc. Bullets will be “plucked” out of the air. Evading beam weapons will be much more difficult, but even if you get scorched on the way out, you are re edited back on board the ship.A lot of story lines die out as well. There are no space miners - a mining ship comes along and beams the lovely dilithium crystals right out of the rocks and into the cargo bay. Same for space farmers - even people who want to farm will be doing it in virtual space.Which means the entire “economy” is mostly dedicated to gathering energy and raw materials. Earth is embedded in a Dyson swarm to provide the energy for running trillions of transporters and associated devices. The Star Trek Universe There are so many other potential implications of transporter technology that I have only scratched the surface. So Star Trek world building needs to be totally redone to reflect the implications of transporter technology.

Get rid of the holodeck. Cool idea? Yes. Badly used? Yes, and yes, and yes. What else? Hm…some of the best (and the worst) episodes of ToS ended the crisis, and then the clean up started. Think “A Taste of Armageddon”. Kirk gets the two sides to stop fighting and talk to each other. As the episode ends, the final message from Ambassador Fox is that peace negotiations have started, and the outlook is hopeful. Think “Devil in the Dark”. Kirk and Spock establish communication with the Horta, explain to the miners that they’ve been destroying the Horta’s eggs, and arrange a modus vivendi between the Horta and the miners. The final message from Vandenberg - “the Hortas are ugly but you could get used to them”. Spock comments the Horta had the same feeling about humans. They’re not best friends - they’ve just decided to leave each other alone and maybe work together. Maybe after a time there might be trust, then friendship. “Arena”. “Return of the Archons”, “The Apple”. “The Cloud Minders”. All of these find the Enterprise confronted by a problem, and the Enterprise destroys or neutralizes or corrects whatever or whomever is causing the problem to not be fixed. But when the Enterprise leaves the planet, the problem still needs to be fixed. By contrast, I found that TNG tended to make really interesting and severe problems, and then someone finds the magical solution and - poof - everything is solved and tied up with a neat bow. The one that really grated was the episode where the Romulans are secretly supporting one side in the Klingon civil war. The Enterprise stops one Romulan supply convoy, and the forces of Duras collapse, and the war is almost over. It would have been more interesting to see the civil war continue, and Duras and his family have to try to hold their side together after it had been demonstrated that they were getting support from the Romulans. But no. There are lots of other examples, but because I’ve seen the ToS episodes many many times I can easily recall them. Not so, for me, with the TNG episodes. Get rid of the nice, neat, bow tie endings.

Most of my problems involve poor character development for Yar, Troi, and Worf. And then there are consistency issues… I would have left out Tasha Yar entirely or given her a role of “weapons officer” and made Worf security chief from the beginning. I would also have had a dedicated communications officer, like on the original series, since that job really does require a lot of work. (As a ham radio operator, I know how challenging radio operation really is.)Left Troi off the bridge. She was criminally underused through much of her time on the series (she really only got two or three really good episodes), and she spent more time as a love interest than being used for her telepathic powers. I get why she was so often “away”, because she would have seen through some of the plots in seconds, ending the conflict before the third act. So if that’s the case, she should simply not be part of the main cast - instead only being used for diplomatic missions and times where her specific talents are needed. The rest of the time, she should be in the medical center, treating patients and doing psychological research.Just like Crusher didn’t have a seat on the bridge, neither should Troi have had her own chair.Worf never got to be the hero. Instead, he was the show’s punching bag. He needed some glorious moments, which he eventually got in DS9. I’d like to have seen more great Worf moments. Likewise, Worf was a terrible father… and I lay this mostly at terrible writing. Even if Alexander was off screen most of the time, he should have been around, and Worf never should have sent his son off to his parents.Consistency of units of measure and other details: In one episode, a ship with “limited speed” can travel 15 light years in a day, but we later learn (in Voyager) that the maximum sustained speed of a a starship is around 1000c. This means a starship can (roughly) travel 3 light years per day. So a “slow” cargo ship should have been able to make less than 1 light year per day. Those kinds of mistakes annoy me to no end.

Obviously, I would have doubled down on the men in skorts. Every man would be in a skort, all the time.  Also, I would have tweaked the characters to amplify their purported reasons to be on the show. Most of the characters were, as written, too conservative in what they were supposed to be. Picard: Leave him as he is. He’s marvelous. Riker: Was billed as an ambitious hotshot. This was dropped after the first few episodes. I think it would have been a fine approach to the character. An ambitious hotshot would’ve come into conflict with Picard in a reversal of the Kirk/Spock dynamic, and once we got attached to him, we would’ve been worried that he was going to seek a promotion and leave the crew. Or the writers could have played up the lothario bit and made it a character flaw for him to overcome as he matures enough for Deanna to give him a second shot. Or . . . anything, really. There was never much to work with for Riker. I don’t feel that the boat was missed, because I never figured out what the boat was. Data: Fan-friggin’-tastic. Leave him as he is. Worf: Really great character who transitioned smoothly to DS9. My only quibble is that the writers used “this bad guy can throw Worf around like a doll!” to tell us how dangerous the bad guys were. Over and over and over. Worf must’ve weighed thirty pounds. My change: Give us frequent scenes in which Worf is in the background casually mopping the floor with big tough troublemakers or heaving massive objects around and nobody bats an eye because, like, that’s why he’s security, dog. Wesley: Iconic. This character is agonizing and unfixable and has finally come to be deeply cherished by fans everywhere. It took us three decades to understand what a cringey treasure we had in Wesley Crusher. Don’t change a thing. Wil Wheaton forever. Troi: HHHHHHUAHHHHHHHARGHHHHHH *deep breath* Look. Easy fix. It’s the fix that the Picard writers went for, and they did nothing else effectively: Write her as a goddamn therapist. When she lays into Picard and Riker, it’s clear that she’s the only person on screen who’s been paying attention to the traumatized person in front of all of them, and she’s demanding better. It’s beautiful. In her original run, this was such a frustrating misfire after misfire after misfire. Troi’s purpose was clear. We were in the mid eighties; we were getting comfortable with the idea of mental health care. So we put a therapist in space. And then didn’t make her a good therapist. She just . . . mugged at people and had big feelings. I think we came up with the idea but didn’t bother finding out what a therapist was.  And she was supposed to be semi-psychic. She was supposed to be so skilled at taking her species’ natural empathic senses and interpreting them, that she was a walking lie detector, a pro cheerleader, an indispensable advisor to negotiation, and an early warning system for violence. And she never did any of that. She just pulled faces and said things like “I’m sensing . . . hostility” after we saw a big angry alien roar and heard him make threats. Troi’s superpowers actually being super? Also an easy fix. Just cut away the things that make her redundant, to the viewer and to the crew. We’d make the big alien smile and say friendly things, and Troi would say “I’m sensing . . . hostility” and we’d say “Huh?” and then the alien would fire on the ship and we’d say “Shit!” Troi would yell that something’s wrong with the away team, and then we wouldn’t have the bridge crew gape at her and then get a distress call from the away team. We’d just have the bridge crew act on her warning and beam the away team out immediately, without wasting time checking in first. Troi was redundant. She didn’t have to be. Geordi: Wesley’s awkwardness and frankly terrible writing as a sensitive, bright teenager has aged better and better (but lord it’s not good). Geordi’s awkwardness and mediocre writing as a sensitive wanna-be lover has . . . aged very badly indeed. It comes across as condescending to the character and as casually misogynistic. Geordi needs a revamp. Give Geordi some new hobbies that aren’t “trying to hook up with girls.” Make him less naive and more useful in his mentoring relationship with Data. With the benefit of hindsight, the first thing I’d change is the Ferengi. One of Roddenberry’s earliest mistakes was his failure to understand that his evil capitalists could not simultaneously be threatening and portrayed as comically clueless idiots. I’d want them to be clever, cosmopolitan and operate through charming and pretty representatives. I’d want them to be Gordon Gekko. Above all I’d actually make the Ferengi predatory capitalists. I’d want to see them destroying planetary environments, creating company towns where everyone is in debt to the company store, selling weapons to both sides of local wars, introducing addictive pharmaceuticals into new markets. The Combine would be an evil mirror to the Federation, just as racially diverse (including humans) and expansionist, After that, I’d “fix” Data. Specifically I’d the first episode be the ship investigating the loss of yet another colony and have them encounter both a Ferengi vessel and that the only survivor is an android. They have to figure out if the Ferengi or the android is responsible and whether to yield to the Ferengi claim that they financed the creation of the android and therefore are the rightful owners as well as dealing with the actual cause of the massacre which threatens them both. Eventually the android would be brought aboard but wouldn’t be given a rank. That way deciding whether or not the android was a person on Measure of a Man would still be an open question. I’d seriously consider making the android the eye candy female that every Star Trek series seems to have. After the hearing to decide the android’s legal status, I’d make it the “acting ensign” I’d make Worf the security chief from the start and I’d make sure to include fights he gets to win. And I’m sure the show would get along fine without ever having Wesley.

TNG was a product of its time… Answering this question today, in 2020, seems rather unfair to the show. TNG maintained good ratings over its entire run. And compared to the drek that was on TV in the late 1980’s and early 1990’s? TNG is downright amazing. Remember, this was all before streaming… or DVR’s… Or even widespread use of home video recording. Grand schemes to turn it into a ‘modern’ show are just non-starters in the TV environment that it was born in. Further, so many issues in ST:TNG really get back to the absolutely pathetic budget the show had, especially for effects. Want to know why they reused the same five sets for everything? Or why every planet looks the same? Because they literally couldn’t afford to do anything else. I could go on, and I will: So much of the shows “errors” are just a product of the time. The clothing styles, the character traits, even the nature of the federation are all just part of the worldviews of the writers and directors. Oh, and speaking of the writers and directors: TNG writers TNG directors That’s about everybody in Hollywood. Tons of people wrote or directed single episodes. That’s the reality of episodic television of the era, but the reality is that you aren’t going to be able to do the sort of more complex character development in that environment that so many answers call for. While we could point out specifically bad episodes or small errors, the reality is that if any of us went back to 1989, knowing only what we knew then, it’s doubtful we could have made a better show.

Much as I loved Data and Brent Spiner, the show’s representation and writing on his character had one major flaw of believeablity (yes, even for science fiction.) Most of the Data centric stories focussed on him learning something new about how humans think and feel, yet by the time he arrived on the Enterprise, he’d gone through several years at Starfleet Academy, and then over 20 years on active duty. In over 25 years, nobody explained what a joke was? He never once tried dating anyone? He never learned poetry before meeting Beverly Crusher? Not very realistic. I know that some people have tried to explain that the Enterprise crew were the first to treat him as a person rather than a tool or machine, but were that true, there’s no way he’d have been promoted to Lt Commander - that’s not a rank given just by passage of time without getting into trouble, you have to earn it competitively and be selected for the rank. If his commanders prior to Picard had seen him simply as a machine, he would not have been recommended for promotion, nor the awards he’d received (mentioned in the episode Measure of a Man.) After 25 plus years service in Starfleet, he would not have been as android naive as he was portrayed, and if he was, he wouldn’t have been promoted to a rank that qualified him as 2nd officer.

I think that one of the biggest issues with TNG was that the wrote themselves into a corner very early on by not having clear limits of what the technology was capable of. Far too many episodes revolve around some sort of techno-babble or hand waving where some piece of technology needed to be negated to allow for some sense of jeopardy or a problem was solved by some hand waved technological solution. Similarly it was never entirely clear what it was that the Enterprise was actually supposed to be doing. the presence of families with children suggested that it had some sort of diplomatic and science role but you never saw very much of that in practice and the overall feel was still pretty military. You definitely didn’t get much of the feel of exploring the ‘final frontier’ that you did with TOS, and they never seemed that far from somewhere pretty familiar and it failed to convey a sense of relative distance. When you have warp drive what does exploration actually mean anyway ? There are also little details like the fact that they wore exactly the same uniforms when wandering around on the ship as they did when going to explore some potentially hostile planet. Perhaps it was incredibly sophisticated clothing which could cope with any possible climatic extremes but it never really felt like it. It felt like they only went to places which had nice weather. When your exploring clothing is basically a futuristic suit and tie it somewhat take the edge of the sense of exploration. So the overall feel was of a hugely expensive and sophisticated Starfleet flagship that was just sort of bumbling around more or less at random. In fact in terms of story it seemed a bit like what you would get if a modern aircraft carrier went to a different randomly selected port every week and the captain went off on his own to solve crimes. Overall I think that the writing never really managed to establish a solid concept for the series both in terms of what the capabilities and limits of the technology were, which is bad in sci-fi writing and also what the actual point of it was and what they were trying to achieve. Which along with somewhat vague production design made the whole thing a bit disconnected from anything relatable. This was further reinforced by the fact that there was never any real sense of what the Federation was actually like as a place to live, the fundamental politics and economics were only touched on peripherally which again left the motivations of the characters a bit vague. This wasn’t helped by the episodic writing which mostly left everything wrapped up in a single episode often by an inevitable deus ex machina and character development was slow and linear, if it happened at all and indeed most development seemed more like the writers working out what they actually wanted to do with a particular character rather than any really credible trajectory and the whole thing just felt a bit lacking in purpose.

I would urge the crew to, while always striving to obey the Prime Directive, to not always be so quick to reveal its existence as a hard rule and law. Knowledge of the Prime Directive becomes a card to play for the manipulative. Picard and company should have merely emphasized non-interference as a desire, as what they planned to do in the here and now. The one time I think he was justified was to the planetary leader in the (episode) ‘First Contact’ to emphasize their good will and willingness to accept his final decision. But in most circumstances I can recall, it just leads to the most scheming party sitting there taunting them about it. While they are overcome, it also complicates matters. By revealing it, they seem like this awesome power that goes out of its way to hamstring itself. By merely stating the same principles as what they prefer to adhere to, it reassures the positive parties and disarms the underhanded. So obey this law without broadcasting it every time.
